April 13, 1986: Fiction
THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The
hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong.
BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter
family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing.
LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in
a small Minnesota town.
LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman
caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. in Afghanistan.
THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues
her adventures in the prehistoric world.
HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A
semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan.
JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey.
(Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries.
SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $17.95.) A
businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor.
THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the
America of the future men and women perform assigned services.
PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is
seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism.
TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $21.95.) Four hundred fifty
years of history in fictional form.
NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $12.95.) While
fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love.
CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a
vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon.
STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor House, $17.95.) The pursuit of a stolen
crystal with curative powers climaxes atop St. Patrick's Cathedral.
HIGH JINX, by William F. Buckley Jr.  (Doubleday, $16.95.) Blackford Oakes on
the trail of the traitor who spoiled a plan to liberate Albania.
BLACK GENESIS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) Continuing
the science fiction epic begun in ''The Invaders Plan.''
April 13, 1986
Non-Fiction
YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random  House, $9.95.) A checkup at
the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults.
BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip
with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love.
THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, $18.95.) The life and loves of J.
Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at  Ford and Chrysler.
YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.)
From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster
than sound.
WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of
Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family.
BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. (Knopf, $17.95.) The
autobiography of the distinguished English actor.
THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit,
$15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological
disabilities.
ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton  Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for
76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic.
GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken Auletta. (Random House,
$19.95.) The fall of the investment bankers Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse,
with drawings by the author.
ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Scribners, $22.95.) A rhapsodic report on
human and  life north of the Arctic Circle.
ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.)
The television reporter tells of people he's encountered while journeying around
America.
DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st
year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new
visions of the past and future.
NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and  Speed Vogel. (Putnam, $18.95.)
